awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Expansion, Optimization, and Dissemination of Step-Based Tutoring Software for Linear Circuit Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, Arizona State University, in collaboration with Morgan State University, Florida A&M University, and the University of Texas at El Paso, will evaluate the impact of a virtual tutoring system for circuit analysis. The virtual tutor focuses on introductory linear circuit analysis, a key gateway class required of students in all engineering disciplines. Personalized to handle each student's needs, the tutoring system uses a step-based approach in which the computer accepts each step of a student's work and automatically evaluates the work, providing detailed feedback.  This immediate feedback helps to correct student errors early in the learning process.

This project aims to augment, optimize, disseminate, and evaluate the impact of a virtual tutoring system (Circuit Tutor) for linear circuit analysis. Compared to similar systems, the Circuit Tutor uniquely accepts and checks every step of a student's work to provide immediate, detailed feedback, thus facilitating student learning and minimizing student frustration.  Offered in "open-source" mode, the tutoring system will be freely available to students all over the world.  Methods of optimizing the pedagogical effectiveness of the system will be systematically explored by studying transcripts of student work and by real-time observations of students at work with Circuit Tutor.  Instructors will be provided with an online dashboard to inform them about the progress of individual students and common learning difficulties.  Introduction of "desirable learning difficulties" that are believed to greatly enhance long-term retention will be explored.  Integration of theoretical computer-based instruction with hands-on learning will also be studied.  The software will be rigorously evaluated and results widely disseminated to multiple institutions for use in their engineering courses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project involved a collaboration among four minority-serving institutions, Arizona State University (ASU), University of Texas-El Paso, Florida Agricultural & Mining University/Florida State University, and Morgan State University, to complete the development of a step-based, computer-aided tutoring system called Circuit Tutor to aid in the teaching of a key gateway course in engineering on introductory electrical circuit analysis.  The system was initially developed under two prior NSF grants, and greatly expanded, completed, evaluated, and disseminated under the current grant.  The idea of a step-based tutoring system is to provide immediate feedback on every stage of a student's work when solving homework problems, to maximize learning efficiency and reduce frustration.  Special user interfaces were developed to allow students to re-draw circuit diagrams on screen, to enter equations using a template-based interface, to enter simplified and matrix forms of those equations, to enter multiple-choice and numerical answers, to sketch various types of graphs of waveforms and special plots called "Bode plots" on screen, and to accept and evaluate typewritten algebraic expressions needed in more complex problems.  The system also creates its own problems from scratch, so that each student can access an unlimited supply of unique problems with corresponding fully worked examples and explanations.  The system is available 24/7 to students, and records all of their activity to a central server. 

Key improvements during this grant were the addition of 10 new modules covering many of the most difficult and challenging topics in the course (for a total of 30 modules overall), which also involved especially complicated user interfaces to accept and evaluate student work.  Virtually all of the major topics in the course are now covered by the system.  The system now includes automatic generation of PDF files recording every step of a student's work (both correct and incorrect) for their use in later studying and review, which is something that most electronic homework systems do not provide.  Interactive, multiple-choice introductory tutorials have now been developed on nearly all of the topics, which can potentially replace conventional textbooks at no cost.  An instructor dashboard (in addition to the gradebook) has been added, which allows instructors to carefully monitor student progress in their sections.  A total of 87 help videos demonstrating the solution of the various types of problems in the system and showing students exactly how to use the user interfaces have now been published on YouTube. 

The system has now been used by a total of 10,660 students in 298 class sections taught by 76 distinct instructors at 18 distinct colleges and universities (7 of them being minority-serving institutions).  It has therefore had very broad impact on diverse populations of students.  Comprehensive evaluation of the system was carried out by the independent College Research and Evaluation Services Team at ASU using a mixed methods approach, via a combination of student and instructor surveys and document review.  The surveys captured both quantitative and qualitative data using Likert scale items and open-ended questions.  The latest evaluation focused on implementation, usability, and satisfaction across the four participating campuses.  Key findings included that "Taken together across both semesters, 95% of the students across all institutions strongly agreed or somewhat agreed that CT [Circuit Tutor] was useful in helping them understand the class content, 84% prefer CT exercises to other homework systems, and 77% agreed to the same extent they would like to use CT again."  Further, the report found that "The instructor findings showed that 100% of them would recommend that other institutions use CT and felt the administrative support was adequate.  Additionally, 86% of instructors reported that CT was much more or somewhat more effective than the other homework system previously used to teach linear circuit analysis and 72% reported using CT made teaching their class much easier or somewhat easier compared to other homework systems used to teach the class."  Rigorous randomized, controlled experiments comparing nine different CT modules to paper homework or commercial publisher-based systems were also carried out during this grant to evaluate student learning.  Five of the modules showed statistically significant improvements on post-tests compared to paper or publisher homework with effect sizes of 0.54, 0.64, and 0.61 standard deviations in some class sections, but no significant difference in other sections (where students were academically stronger). 

Important intellectual contributions were also made by this project in the fundamentals of the subject, including improved definitions of basic concepts like series connections and circuit "meshes," as well as in an important analysis method called mesh analysis.  These improvements are based on a unifying principle called duality, which can help students more readily understand the subject.  Six conference papers and a journal paper were published during this grant and three workshops were given at conferences for other instructors on the use of the system, which is freely available to all.
